verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, 'Depart, go up from here, you and the people whom you have brought out of the land of Egypt, to the land I swore to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob, saying, "To your descendants I will give it."'
verses.comment: God reiterates the promise He made to the patriarchs. Notice the emphasis on God's covenant faithfulness, a key theme throughout Scripture and a pointer toward the new covenant established in Christ (see Luke 1:72-73).

verses.text: 'I will send an angel before you, and I will drive out the Canaanite, the Amorite, the Hittite, the Perizzite, the Hivite, and the Jebusite.'
verses.comment: God promises angelic guidance—interpreted by some Church Fathers as a foreshadowing of Christ, who is both messenger and the very presence of God among His people.

verses.text: 'Go up to a land flowing with milk and honey. But I will not go up among you, lest I consume you on the way, for you are a stiff-necked people.'
verses.comment: Separation from the direct presence of God is a result of sin, hinting at the need for mediation and atonement, later fulfilled in Christ's sacrificial ministry.

verses.text: When the people heard this disastrous word, they mourned, and no one put on his ornaments.
verses.comment: The Israelites' mourning reflects true contrition, the beginning of repentance and restoration—a model for sincere repentance, later deepened in Christian spiritual practice.

verses.text: For the LORD had said to Moses, 'Say to the people of Israel, "You are a stiff-necked people. If for a single moment I went up among you, I would consume you. Now, take off your ornaments, that I may know what to do with you."'
verses.comment: Removal of ornaments signals humility before God. This act of penance echoes later Christian traditions of outward signs of repentance (see Matt. 6:17).

verses.text: So the people of Israel stripped themselves of their ornaments from Mount Horeb onward.
verses.comment: This public act of humility prepares them to receive God's mercy, highlighting the importance of physical gestures in worship and penance.

verses.text: Now Moses used to take the tent and pitch it outside the camp, far off from the camp, and he called it the Tent of Meeting. And everyone who sought the LORD would go out to the Tent of Meeting, which was outside the camp.
verses.comment: The Tent of Meeting outside the camp shows Israel’s separation from God's presence due to their sin. Yet God still allows access via an intercessor—Moses—prefiguring the ultimate Mediator (see 1 Tim. 2:5).

verses.text: Whenever Moses went out to the Tent, all the people would rise and stand at the entrance of their tents, watching Moses until he entered the Tent.
verses.comment: The respect shown to Moses’ approach illustrates communal reverence for God's appointed leadership and the ongoing tradition of visible priestly roles in guiding the people.

verses.text: When Moses entered the Tent, the pillar of cloud would descend and stand at the entrance of the Tent, and the LORD would speak with Moses.
verses.comment: The pillar of cloud—God’s visible presence—foreshadows the Incarnation, when the invisible God became visible in Christ (see John 1:14).

verses.text: And when all the people saw the pillar of cloud standing at the entrance of the Tent, all the people would rise and worship, each at the entrance of his tent.
verses.comment: The people's worship from afar shows the distance from God's holiness, but their unity in worship also prefigures the communal aspect of Christian worship.

verses.text: Thus the LORD used to speak to Moses face to face, as one speaks to his friend. When Moses turned again into the camp, his assistant Joshua the son of Nun, a young man, would not depart from the Tent.
verses.comment: God’s unique intimacy with Moses foreshadows the fuller revelation in Jesus, who calls His disciples friends (see John 15:15). Joshua’s remaining in the Tent hints at apostolic succession and continuity of leadership.

verses.text: Moses said to the LORD, 'See, you say to me, "Bring up this people," but you have not let me know whom you will send with me. Yet you have said, "I know you by name, and you have also found favor in my sight."'
verses.comment: Moses’s plea for clarity demonstrates the importance of personal relationship with God and the assurance of divine favor given to those set apart for God’s purposes.

verses.text: Now therefore, if I have found favor in your sight, please show me your ways, so that I may know you and find favor in your sight. And consider too that this nation is your people.
verses.comment: Moses intercedes for the people and desires to know God deeply. This pursuit of divine knowledge and intercession foreshadows Christ, the perfect intercessor (see Heb. 7:25).

verses.text: And he said, 'My presence will go with you, and I will give you rest.'
verses.comment: God’s promise of His presence and rest points to Christ, who offers true rest to souls (see Matt. 11:28), indicating a spiritual Sabbath in Him.

verses.text: And he said to him, 'If your presence will not go with us, do not bring us up from here.'
verses.comment: Moses understands that God’s presence is the only thing that gives the people true identity and protection—a principle fundamental to all of Christian life and worship.

verses.text: For how shall it be known that I have found favor in your sight, I and your people? Is it not by your going with us, so that we are distinct, I and your people, from every other people on the face of the earth?'
verses.comment: God's presence among His people sets them apart, prefiguring the new people of God, distinct through God's indwelling Spirit and sanctifying grace.

verses.text: And the LORD said to Moses, 'This very thing that you have spoken I will do, for you have found favor in my sight, and I know you by name.'
verses.comment: God’s response emphasizes the power of intercessory prayer and mediation. The idea that God “knows by name” His elect is beautifully echoed in Christian theology about divine election and grace.

verses.text: Moses said, 'Please, show me your glory.'
verses.comment: Moses' desire to see God's glory anticipates the Incarnation, where the Word is made flesh and God’s glory is fully revealed in Christ.

verses.text: And he said, 'I will make all my goodness pass before you and will proclaim before you my name "The LORD." I will be gracious to whom I will be gracious, and will show mercy on whom I will show mercy.'
verses.comment: God’s self-revelation stresses absolute sovereignty in grace and mercy. Paul cites this to teach about divine election (see Rom. 9:15).

verses.text: But, he said, 'You cannot see my face, for man shall not see me and live.'
verses.comment: The gap between God and humanity is emphasized here; the full vision of God is reserved until the beatific vision, ultimately enabled by Christ.

verses.text: And the LORD said, 'Behold, there is a place by me where you shall stand on the rock,'
verses.comment: The 'rock' is a physical place for encountering God’s presence, which Paul later interprets spiritually as Christ Himself (see 1 Cor. 10:4).

verses.text: And while my glory passes by I will put you in a cleft of the rock, and I will cover you with my hand until I have passed by.
verses.comment: God’s protection of Moses from the full glory points to the need for mediation, fulfilled in Christ as the only one who reveals God fully and safely.

verses.text: Then I will take away my hand, and you will see my back; but my face shall not be seen.
verses.comment: Even Moses could only glimpse a partial revelation. The fullness of God is revealed in Christ (see John 1:18), but remains mysterious until the final vision of God in glory.
